newsitem.title: FINLAND: Finnish H1 state finance deficit falls - fin min.
newsitem.headline: Finnish H1 state finance deficit falls - fin min.

text.p: The Finnish finance ministry said on Thursday that state revenue increased while state spending fell in the first half of 1997 compared to the year-ago period, narrowing the deficit of state finances.
State revenue excluding borrowing increased 1.1 percent in January-June to 90.2 billion markka while state expenditure excluding debt amortisation fell 1.2 percent to 108.7 billion.
The deficit of the state finances narrowed to 18.5 billion markka from 20.8 billion in the first half of 1996, the ministry said in a statement.
The figures were released in connection with the five-party government's three-day negotiations on the 1998 state budget proposal which started on Wednesday.

The state's tax and related revenues rose 6.9 percent to 66.1 billion markka in the first half, the ministry said. The increase stemmed mainly from a 2.5 billion markka extra collection of corporate incolme tax, it said.

Overall, income tax collection rose 16.8 percent year-on-year to 73 billion markka and the state's 25.6 billion markka slice was 18.6 pecent higher. Value added tax revenue rose 2.5 percent to 22.1 billion markka, the ministry said.
On the expenditure side, state transfers to households fell 8.7 percent to 20.5 billion markka, while transfers to municipalities rose 21.1 percent to 21.9 billion.
The state's debt servicing costs fell 10.7 percent year-on-year to 16.5 billion markka, the ministry said.
